India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June 4, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m., for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai)El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: German Colonial Policy
div.p: "Count co man happy until ha is dead," said the sage of old. 'Cjunt no Gsven meut happy that ia in any degree dependent upon the good pleasure of & legislative assembly until honourable members have been safely pxoked off home for the summer Reoess," a cynioal politician might say at the prWer.t time; for, so long as Parliament .is si ting, you never know what s-orvy trick the''Out, may have up their sleeve for the confusion of the "Ina." It is in consequence of * that particular phase of the uncertainty of human affsirs that the German Government has been badly beaten in the Reichstag, jqgj whea that body was looking forward to adjourning, until November. The cause of the trouble was the demand of the Government for certain votes of credit for the military opera- tions in South West Africa, and.the proposal to create a separate Colonial Department to be oontJbiled by the Colonial Secretary of State. Now, although we certainly do not know any- thing approachirg the sum total of the losses in purse, in personnel,, and ih prestige which Germany has saffered in the troublesome oolohial war in which she has been so long engaged in the vast traots. cf South wbtt Africa o which her 11 tg Hi s, yet enough has leaked out—in spite ot official precautions -to create a strong current of popular feeling against the wh He colonial policy of the Empire. The remit was that the Reichstag practi cally refused the whole of the credits required, Lr black troops in East Afrioa,'Compeusafoi for losses to colonists, and railway extension. Furthermore, the depities peremptori'y de- manded a redaction in the numbers of the forces ia the field, and the complete evacua- tion of the southern portion of the Colony, and refused the vote to establish a Colonial 8scre- tary. This thoroagh-going policy - your Ger- is nothing if not thoroagh—might pos- have been modified at the request of the IXrector of the Colonial Department had not the government's evil star shot a ray of 8uggestion\|nto the brain of Colonel von Daimling, Government Commissary, and suc- cessor-designate the tracalentVon Trotba. The gallant ColoneNw a Prussian officer of the true ramrod school^^ho would have been dear to the heart of the grb^t Frederick. Was the health of the troops bad asked. Why certainly; it was simply terrible^wmrse than it had ever been before. Bat that wsjSaHjthe more reason for not leaviug the railway in the mud at Kabab." As~to the proposed evacuation of the south : "SJ long as I have "lie honour to hold the command the south- "ern districts will not be abandoned unless "my Emperor issues a command to that effect, "and it is he alone who has to decide, and no "one else." Jast cmceive the effect of that i>jup de cravache upon the oivilian shoulders of the deputies in general and for the Social Democrats in ^rticalar! The game was up, the demands were refased, and the House aljoarn ed. It is, of course, clear that Colonel Von Deimling's challenge to the Reichstag has resulted in a oonnter-chal'enge by that assembly to the Kaiser and his Chancellor. The Imperial Diet challenges the Imperial Colonial polioy, and, we may safely say, the entire policy, of the powers that be for all matters not of a purely dome J tic nature. There can, indeed.be no doubt that there is grave disodatent with the policy of Qnrest and adventure which in the diploma- tic, as in the colonial, sphere ha9 not tended to enhance the prestige of Germany, or to foster good relations between her and other Powers. More than that: Colonel von Deimling has gra- tuitously raised the whole question of the rela- / tions between theCrown and tbelmperial Diet. By a onrioos coincidence we find the agent cf the German Government praotioally paraphrasing the reply of the Russian Government to the Dnma. There is the same note of absolute autooracy, the same assertion of the ultimate snpremaoy of the Imperial will Now, if the new-horn Russian Duma is not disposed to tolerate that pretension, it is not to be sup- posed that the German Reiohstag, which is in the full vigour of its five-and-thirty years' life, will prove more submissive to a crude and bratal assertion of the dootrine that the last word lies with "my Emperor." Here, then, we have a situation which involves much larger questions than any connected with the re- tention or abandonment of any portioL of a barren and costly possession which is not so * much a jewel in the Imperial crown as a cock's oimb on the cap of a Conrt fool. It really matters little whether Germany retains her South-West Afrioan oolony or not j for, if there is any jealousy in the Cape Colony of her presence on our fiink, that is due rather to the sentimental feeling in favour of the geogra- phical unity of British South Africa from the Zambesi to the sea, Thanks to drought, fever, and the Kalahari desert, there is practically no strategical importance in theGermanpossessicu of those regions as a menace to the Cape Colony. The Garman?, therefore, may please them- selves as to what they keep or let go in that luarter, and it is not surprising that they doubt whether the present game is worth the vary costly candle. But Colonel von Deimling —simple Prussian martinet that he is—has raised the whole question of the constitutional ight of the German people to have a say in any matter of world-polioy, small or great. He has thrown down a challenge which the Reiohstag has taken np—promptly and hotly —and, though nothing, we suppose, cf aoy vast importance will come of that challenge for the moment, yet reoent proceedings in the Reiohstag may, some day, be looked back upon as a milestone in the progress of the supreme struggle for the evolution of full constitutional government for Germany, of the sort which is "nnderstanded of the people" in lands where o'diers do not talk to the people's represent- atives about "my Emperor,"—"Pall Ma'l Ga-Zette.

div.p: The salving of the Montagu has been re-sumed, the weather having improved. A false bottom, to cover the holes made by the rocks, is in course of construction. The rocks underneath are being blasted with a view to lowing the veseel off. '(Reuter.)

Sind Egyptian Cotton.

The Bombay Agricultural Department have sent home about a score of bales of Egyptian cotton prodaoed in Sind for sale by the British Cotton-Growing Association. The object is to ascertain the true valae in the cotton market at home of the Sind Egyptian cottOn.
Moslem Benevolent Societies

The Benevolent Society ot A1 Malagi el Abbassieh, Alexandria, has been merged in the A1 Orwa el Woska Society, and H H. the Khedive has desired the members of the administration of the latter body to thank H E. Khalil Pacha Hamada, the retiring pre-sident of the Malagi el Abbassieb, in the name of his Highness, for the valuable services that he has rendered to that society.
Fatal Accident

Some native workmen were yesterday demolishing a wall of the trenches at Kom- el Dik, when two of them and the contractors Bon, a youth, who was standing near by, were overwhelmed by a huge mass of debris which fell on them. The boy was killed on tbespot, while the two workmen received very serioos injuries and were taken to hospital, where shortly afterwards one of them sncoumbed to his injuries.

div.head: DAMIETTA. LORD CROMER'S REPLY TO THE DELEGATION. CONCURS IN NEW ARRANGEMENT
div.p: Lord Cromer has sent the following reply to the delegation of the inhabitants of Damietta, who laid their grievances before him :— Gentlemen,—I have carefully considered the representations which yon have made to me on the subject of the proposed administrative changes afieoting the town if Da mifctta, and I li.ve been made acquainted with the views entertained on this question by His Excellency the Minister and by the Adviser to the Interior. It is to be remembered that, in dealing with this matter, it is not 'only the interests of the town of Damietta which have to be considered ; those of the inhabitants of the rural districts in that neighbourhood have an equal claim on the attention of JHis Highness's Government. «It is hoped and believed that the arrangement at which the Ministry of the Interior baa now arrived, after a careful examination of the facts of the case and of the arguments adduced, will he found to satisfy the very well- founded claims of the latter, without in any way inflicting ii jury on the commercial prospects of yonr ancient and celebrated city. I have therefore expressed my full concurrence in this arrangement, of the details of which you will be informed in^ communication which is now being addressed to yon by the Ministry of the Interior. I have little doubt that in a short while the results of the system now to be inaugurated will have proved themselves satisfactory, and that the inhabitants of Damietta will reoognise that the fears which they have recently expressed were groundless.—I am, Gentlemen, etc., (Signed) CROMER

div.head: THE WORCESTER'S LEAVING.
div.p: We regret to hear that the. 4th Battalion Woicestersbire Regiment will 'e»y probably be withdrawn from Alexandria to Malta in a fortnight's time. During their short stay the officers and men of the battalion have made themselves deservedly popular and they will b) greatly missed when they leave Alexandra.

div.head: RIOT IN THE SUDAN. OFFICERS AND MEN KILLED.
div.p: An affray has taken place between the inhabitants of Talondi village, in the Bouth of Kordnfan Moudirieh, and the local garrison. Two Egyptian officers and some men of the 12th Sudanese are reported to have been killed. No particnlars explaining the incident, haw been as yet received, but a large reinforce-ment has been despatched to Talondi from El Obeid, under the command of BimbaQji, O'Connell Bey. White troops frontKhajftonm have been sent to replace those oeqmtched from El Obeid. We understand that no importance is attached to this affair by official circles. A riot between black troops and Arab villagers is all that is believed to have occurred, but troops are being sent to the spot to gnard again* t any farther disturbance, and an enquiry will be held into the causes of the outbreak.

div.head: THE PILGRIMMAGE. DECLARED TO BE OVER.
div.p: At this morning's meeting of the Quaran-tine Board, the 1906 pilgrimage was declared to be over. As, however, plague exists at Jeddah, pilgrim steamers which may arrive from the Hedj^z will be subject to the nsnal sanitary regime. The same regime will be applied to all pilgrims arriving by way of laud.

div.head: THE PLAUGE
div.p: Another case of bubonic plagae occurred at Alexandria to day, the patient being a ghaffir of Gabbari station, who lives at Kafr Achri, in the Minet-el-Bassal kism. He was admitted to hospital this morning. The quarantine restrictions on the departure of vessels from Alexandria have been rein foroed in consequence.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive spent yesterday at Ma- riont, aqd spends to day at Montazah Palace. The Austrian Lloyd S.S. Africa, which has been chartered to convey the Khedivial family to Constantinople, is expected to arrive at A'exandria this evening or to-morrow morning. The steamer will sail, with the Khedivial family and suite on board, on Thursday morning. Zaki Pacha and Izzat Bey will aooompany his Highness to Constantinople, where be will stay about a fortnight. Ou the Khedive pro-ceeding to Europe, Shefik Bey, who accom-panied H.H.the Khedivah Mother to Constan-tinople, win retarn to Cairo j and Izzet Bey will stay at the Tnrkish capital until his Highness returns there. To morrow morning at 9 o'clock the Khedive will visit the Abou-el-Abbas Mosqne, where he will inspect the theological Btadents, as he did last year before his departure for Europe. The Chancellor of A1 Azhar University and the Grand Mnfti of Egypt, who arc coming down to Alexandria this evening, will be present at the ceremony. It is now said that H.H. the Khedive does not intend to visit London this summer.

div.head: BRITAIN'S FOREIGN CONSULS
div.p: Mr. Thomas Roberts writes from the Carlton Hotel, Balkeley, to the "Daily News," as follows : "In my oapaoity as British Industrial Agent abroad, I wish to draw attention to the nationality of many of our Conan's. Why are foreigners appointed to such positions, which really call for every British trait and quality ? "Can any rational person expect these men to serve Britain loyally ? In my opinion at the present time we require every position, commercial or otherwise, safely guarded by men of our own blood, from whem we may justly expect patriotism."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: T.E. the Ministers will ccme down from Cairo to Alexandria to-day to wish good bye to H.H. the Khedive on his departure for Constantinople

H.H. the Khedive has presented his photograph to H E Mustapha Pacta Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria ; Khalil Paoha Hamada, snbdirector of Cnatoms, and M. Gennadip, the retiring Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, who is leaving for Athens on the 23rd inst. M. Gennadis has also received the 1st Class of the Order of the Medjidieh.
The Moudir of Dakahlieh has been granted three months' leave, from the 26th inst

The engagement is announced of Captain George Sorel-Cameron, Cameron Highlanders, president of theBahr el-Ghszal ReoroitingCommission, and Marguerite, elder daughter of the Hon. Hamilton Tollemacho and of Mrs. Hamilton Tollemache, 1, Halkin-plsce.
The marriage of Ibrahim Bey Wagnih, judge of the Native Tribunal of Cairo, to the eldest daughter of H.E. Ahmed Yehia Paoha, of Alexandria, will be privately celebrated on Sunday next in Cairo.

div.head: THE PORTE AND TRIPOLI ANOTHER POSSIBLE CAUSE OF FRICTION
div.p: In a message from Constantinople a cor-respondent of the "Manchester Guardian" points out another possible canre of cor A ct with Egypt which he avers the Sultan is secretly preparing. The Porte has received, he-tftates?\fron) the Tnrkish authorities in Tripoli, a report'whioh says that Jarabub, in the frontier region between Egypt and the Benghazi district, forms an integral part of that district, and farther that so far the Kbedivial Government had not exercised there >any effective administrative powers. The Saltan has therefore ordered the authorities of Benghazi qnietly to fend to Jarabub a small contingent of troops to take possession of the district before Egypt taker steps to oconpy it. The Benghazi authorities have received or-ders to act qniokly, because, according to the information of the Porte, the Sennssi Sheikh has quitted the oasis of Kufra and is return-ing to Jarahab, which the Turks obviously wish to occupy before he gets there. When the Sheikh has abandoned Kufra the Saltan has thoughts of oooapyiug the oasis. The Ottoman Government attaohes so much importance to keeping these movements secret that the authorities iu Tripoli and Benghazi have been instructed to refuse the usual permits to foreign explorers and travellers. The frontier line between Tripoli and Egypt is uncertain, bat in praotioe it appears to be generally accepted that Jarabub is in Tripoli. Jarabub is important both as a strategic point ar.d as the saored place of the S9nussi, for the founder of the society, Sidi Mohamed, lies boned there. His son is now the head of the society, and in 1894 moved with several thonsand followers from Jarabub to the oasis of Kufra, from which the correspondent now describes him as returning. The Senussi are bitterly opposed, to Europeans and their civilisation.

div.head: THE SINAI MISSIONS
div.p: The Egyptian Boundary Commissioners, with the Ottoman delegates, will be two months in the Sinai Peninsula determining the principal points of measurement with all the exactitude needed to follow the diplomatic line to its true distances, and on/the agreed western sides of Wadi Rafah and Akaba. The completion of the survey between the leading points, and the erection of intermediate boundaries, will devolve upon the geodesic surveyors accompanyiug the Commission. ("Daily Mail").

div.head: CHEAPER POSTAGE. REDUCTIONS MADE BY POSTAL CONGRESS.
div.p: In the House of Commons last Tuesday, Mr Bux'ou informed Mr. W. Benn that, al-though the British de'egates failed to obtain a redaction in the initial postage rate of 2|d. to foreign countries, they were successful in persuading the congress to adopt two con-siderable concessions to the public—the one as regarded the initial weight allowed for foreign letters and the other as regarded the ohargea on heavier letters. In reference to the first point, wlnn~the new Postal Union Convention of Rome took effect next year the unit of weight would be doubled, so that the existing postage of 2$d. to foreign countries would prepay a letter weighing up to one ounce, instead of up to only half an onnee as at present. This concession would embrace all letters sent under the Imperial penny post to any part of the British Empire and to Egypt, which letters at present most not exoeed half an ounce for a penny. Thna a letter, say, to France, weighing an ounce, wonld in fntnre cost for postage 2|d. instead of 5d., and a similar letter to India and the Colonies would cost Id. instead of 2d. As regarded the seoond point, at present an additional 2jd. was charged for every additional half an onnoe after the first. In fatnre the postage on foreign letters exceeding an ounce would be reduced to l|d. foreaoh additional onnoei after the initial rate of 2}d. on the first ounce had been paid. Thus a letter to France weighing 2oz. wonld be chargeable with a postal rate of 4d.—namely, 2|d. plus ljd.—instead of lOd. as at present. Similarly a 2oz. letter to India, the Colonies, and Egypt would cost only 2d. instead of 4d. A further usefal postal reform which was adopted on the motion of the British delegates was the introduction of a reply ooup'on, a little postal order to bearer, exchangeable in any country for a union postage Btamp. Farther, the transit rates had been reduced and simplified. He thought the British delegates were to be congratulated on the general success which had attended their efforts.

NEWS FROM BEYROUT. ELECTRIC TRAMWAY CONCESSION. A SECOND HELOUAN. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Beyrout, May 28. Since writing last we have had two events of public interest : 1st, the Kermesso given ip the garden of Rnstem Pasha, under the patronage c f the Governor General of Mount Lebanon and Madame Muzaffer Pasha, in aid of the hospital for the Baabda prisoners ; 2dly, the grande fote organised by the Socfotd Fran^aise de Bienfaisance in favour of its works, and in aid of the victims of the Coorrfores oatastrophp, under the patronage of M. Fonqae\ Daparo, the French Consul- General, and the Deputies of the French com-munity The f irmer was a snccess financially— over 12,003 frs. having been collected—bnt otherwise was a failure for various reasons, amongst which was the olondy and rainy weather, which many of the well-known members of society, who felt dnty-bonnd to make an appearance, took as an exouse for non-attendance. The latter ffite was a snccess in every way, and ended with a ball. I had not the pleasure of attending this fote, but I am told that the monologoes were one of the most successful features of the function, and I do not wonder at the fact, for I had once before heard Mr. Wiet, the French Vioe-Consnl, deolaim at a private soiree, and the warmth, life, and enthusiasm he puts in his recitals, and the music d intonation of his voice, were delightfully inspiring. The Talk of tho Day. The talk of the day hero is the eleotrio tramway for Beyroat and the supplementary project of making of the Bandy tracts, about three miles south of Beyrout, within the Lebanon frontier, a second Helonan. A rumour with some element of seriousness in it has been in oircnlation for some weeks past that Nejib Pasha Melhanfo had obtained the concession for an electric tramway for Beyroat, and disposed of it to a Belgian company for 900,000 francs.The figure does seem exorbitant, but it has been actually affirmed to ma by the receiver of the telegraphic mesiage, who is a well-known man, and who has the management of an important concern which is apt to be vitally affeoted by the realization of the eleotric tramway scheme. It is stated that the Gas Company of Beyrout has, according to its firmaD, the exclusive right ami monopoly of lighting the town, and if this' is so it may make a good round sum from the tramway company against the cession of this right to it. It is said that despite the very able management and initiative of the present director, and the running of the company's business on striotly economic lines, the concern is not yet a paying one, so that a mutually profitable entente with the electrio company should be welcomed by the shareholders of the Gas Company. Indeed, the principal shareholder (who praotioally owns the concern) left a few days ago for Constantinople, apparently with this object in view. Much as we sympathize with Mr. S. Eid for his possible failure in his initial attempt at obtaining/the concession we welcome the news^of Nejib Pacha Melha- nfo's reported snccass/'Uofar, however, it is said that the Imperial iradd has not been pro-mulgated, and in fact the official gazette of Constantinople has not yet published the news. Egyptian Financiers Interested. The rumour about the supplementary pro-ject of transforming the sandy dunes of the Uzai into a garden oity started in the following shape? An Anglo-Egyptian company was said to have bought the vast property there owned by the Tabet brothers and their partners, with the view of slotting them on the same lines as the Meadi of the Delta Land Co. Since then a modified version of the story has been ourrent. The Tabets and their partners were to undertake the allotment, interesting in the scheme at the same time a set of Egyptian financiers. There is co donbt that, were the eleotrio tramway to extend a line to that well-known 8nbarban district—and the extension would not cost muoh, in view of the short distance — the scheme would prove a brilliant success. The exceptionally healthy climate—the place being surrounded by vast pine forests, olean sandy tracts, and the sea beyond—the superb panoramio views commanded from every spot, and last, but cot least, the faot of the land being within the Lebanon frontier, enjoying a peaceful rule and a practical exemption from taxation, all these should constitute manifest advantages that every sensible oitizen of Bsyront should be quick to appreciate. Recrudescence of Lawlessness. The repeated commission reoently of lawless aots in the shape of nootnrnal assaults and murders on innocent and respeotable Christians, makes a residence in the Lebanon within a lew minutes ran from Beyroat a universal desideratum. People are wondering at this sadden recrudescence of lawlessness, and some talk of designs on the part of Moslems to repeat the bloody drama of Raohid Bey's time and love to associate thesehostile anti-Christian manifestations with the Akaba affair. But no donbt an excited imagination plays an important part iu all those comments and prognostications, and oar peaceful and enlightened Vali should offer to thefe nervous pessimists a safe gua-rantee against any such outbreak of the Moslem fanatioal temper.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. CRICKET. CAIRO, ALEXANDRIA
div.p: BXCITINO FINISH.

This cricket match—the fourth between Cairo and Alexandria this year—was'clayed on the A. C. C.'8 ground yesterday. Coniiddrable interest was taken in the game, the Alexandria' XL being very strong in all department*. Cairo had not quite their best side, but\ere also abla to put a good XI. io the field\ Play began at 11.0 a.m. and off the firsts, ball bowled—a bad longtop—Capt. Palmer, ' who opened the innings for Alexandria with MacLaren, was well canght at square fog. Off the next Deans was missed. Play then ruled quiet till 20, when Deans was caught at mid-off. H. P. Carver aud McLaren then took the score op to 44, when Capt. Bostock relieved Wyatt, who had bowled well but with bad luok and got MacLareu oaught at • extra cover off his3 first ball. Marsden offered a stubb ire defence and the score rose slowly to 70, when Carver was oaught in trying to hook. At 78 Graves-'going on at lha top end got Marsden canght at the wicket and Capt. Laing fog before. • Peel and Jltreet kept up their wickets till lanch-time Wien the soore was 106 for six wiokets. The Cairo fielding was good and the bowling steady. After lnnch Street and Mastard made a good stand of 55 runs when Mastard was oat l.b.w. He played a good forcing' innings, hitting one six, nine fours, aud two singles. Street was out direotly afterwards for a very good effort of 42 and Barnard being well canght by Wyatt, the innings closed for 181. Sergt. Simpson, Capt. Bostook, and Graves met with most enooesR with the ball. Wyatt, whose fielding" was remarkably good, had no look as a bowler. Cairo began badly to the bowling of Deans and Capt. Laing, bat Capt. Bostook and Stoat improved matters, bringing the soore . to 67, when Bostook was brilliantly canght by Marsden at mid-on. A collapse followed in spite of some free hitting by Capt MoMurdo and Wyatt, and with nine men out 118, owing to some good work by Mastard and Capt. Laing, the match eeemed over. Sergt. Simpson and Drawer, however, refused to be intimidated by the situation and scored as freely as if they had gone in first and when at 155 Drower gave a hard chance to Carver at deep square leg which was not accepted and followed up with several foars it sedmqd that Cairo hada chance. Sergt Simpson made some fine leg hits and with the score at 177 Drower with a strong on-drive tied the soores. In the next over Sergt. Simpson played the ball si iwly to the off and oalfod.his partner for a short ran which came off and Cairo had won a desperately close and exoiting game. The innings closed for 195 when Drower was bowled. He had eight fours to his credit in a remarkably good innings. Sergt. Simpson, who was not ont for 44, hit a five and seven fonrs and played good, free and confident cricket all throngh. Soore and analysis :— ALEXANDRIA. Capt Palmer, o. Sob, b. Graves 0 Mr. J. C. div.head: THE PRINCE'S CASE
div.p: JUDGEMENT AGAINST PRINCE

The first Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Court, presided over by M. Prunibres, has given jndg- ment in the''Process des Prinoea.'The judgment has gone.agasint the Princes, wlnae olaims are declared baceless, and who are ordered to pay the costs of the action. We give some of the more important "attendas" of the judgment. L9 Tribunal eto. Attendu qu'b la demande des princes, le gouvernement (Sgyptien oppose ; 1") one irrd cevabilite absolue en raison de la reuonoiation complete que l'anteur de3 demandeors, Ismai pacha et eux m0mes ont donn6 dans leur arrangement sanction!)^ par d6oret do 3 avril 1388 ; au fond 2")eu ordre principal que les art. 40 et Bnivants de la loi de liquidation lu ont conffird la propridtd des biens Dairas Sanieb, sans restriction ni reserve, mais aveo l'obligation pour lui d'assumer anx liea et place do Khedive Ismail les oharges finan- cibres de l'empront Daira Sanieb, et enfin 3°) en ordre toot b fait subsidiaire, les prescriptions acquisitives de 5 et de 15 ans qui ont confirm^ le droit absolu du gouvernement stir ces mfimes biens.Attendu qu'il est dtabli quTsmail pacha gardd le silence au sujet de son alloootion..., et qae la renonciation dont a'agit n'a pas dtd faite dans les termes les plus strictss, ainsi que le vent la loi et que dds lors l'exception d'irreoevabilitd soulevde par le gouvernemeit dgyptien ne saurait etre admise. Attendu que le toxte de la loi est des plu3 olaira et ne pent laisser aucun doute sor fin- tention du ldgislateur d'ddioter que les pro- pridtdsJDairas Sanieh et Khassa sont ddo'.ardes propridtds de l'Etat, qu'il est formel, n'a rien d'obseur, ni d'incertain et n'a pas besoin d'etre interprdtd: Attendu que les demandeors avancent quo le ddcret du 23 Aoftt 1878 relatif & la cession des biens de la famille est ainsi con^a : " nous oddons en toute propridtd par les prdsentes A l'Etat et ce & perpetuity tons les biens " ne sc tronvent pas dans l'art. 40 sus mentioned ce qui indiquerait, d'aprds enx, qu'il a dtd sous entendu que la propridtd des Dairas Sanieh et Khassa pouvait revenir ultdrieurement b Ismail pacha et ses succeiseurs. Attendu que le mot "propridtd'' a b lui seol plus de force que s'il y avait one addition queloonque qui ne pourrait etre qu'une redon dance comma dans l'espdce aotuelle, oh les mots "b perpdtuitd" dtaiant inutiles ; qu'il dd coule done de tout oe qui prdedde que le goo vernement dgyptien ayant obtenu par la loi de liquidation la pleine propridtd des biens Dairas Sanieh et Khassa sans restriction ni rdserve, cette loi doit fitre appliqude et que son appli cation rend dds b prdsent la demande irroce vable. Qu'il faut rechercher si la loi de liquidation qui ddolare les Dairafe Sanieh et Khassa propridtd de l'Etat a fait uqe rdserve quelconque au profit d'lsma'il pacha. Qae la commission supdrieure d'enqudte avait comme attribution de vdrifier, constater et dtedier, mais ne ponvait rien ddcider. Attenda qa'il est sans intdrdt de s'attarder hoonnaltre les opinions personnelles de cheque membre de la commission dmises dans cette premidre partie de ses travaux do moment que les propositions de la Commission sont oon tenues dans le rapport, suivant qa'il est ndeessaire de oiter en grande partie. "En rdsamd, la Commission snpdrienre d'enqufite demande a Son Altesse d'affeoter b la liquidation da ddficit tontes les propridtde immobilisdes de3 Dairas, e'est-b-dire : 1. Les domaines des Dairas Sanieb et Khassa en tant qu'ils laisseront des ressonrees disponibles, aprds le service des emprenta vx- qnels ils sont affeetds." Attenda qa'il est bien evident qae si le rdglement des dettes avait dtd fait dans les conditions prdvues alors, Ismail pacha restant Bonverain absolu, one fois la dette payde tout exoddent devait lui revenir, puisqu'il pereon- nifiait l'Etat et dtait le ddbiteur, mais tout a changd depuis cette dpoque. Attenda que le 23 aoftt 1878, S. A. le Khddive recevait com-munication de ce rapport qui lui dtait faite par le vioe-prdsideDt de la Commission et il rdpon dait: "quant aux conclusions anxquelles vous fitea arrivds je les accepte :• o'est toot naturel que je le fasse, c'ost moi qui ai ddsird ce travail pour If bien de mon pays." Attendu que la Commission ayant la mission de rdgler les relations des Dairas Sanieh et Khassa aveo leurB ordanciers, se demanda tout d'abord si elle pouvait considdrer les biens des Dairas Sanieh et Khassa comma ddfiuitive- ment eddds b l'Etat, les lormalitds du transfert n'ayantpas enoore dtd remplies : Attenda qae la commission qui aurait tenu que le transfert dont s'agit se fit en dehors Q'elle, se rendit oompte que oe transfert sai- vant la loi du pays n'dtsit pas possible par suite du ddpart de S. A. Ismsil pacha et que, d'autre c6td, le nouveau Khddive ne ponvant par ddoret odder des biens qui ne lui apparte- naient pas, la Commission estima qa'il ne s'a- gisBait qne d'une simple formalitd b remplir, la cession de la propridtd des domainess des Daira Sanieb et Khassa b l'Etat dtant ddficitive de la part d'lamail pacha ; elle ddcida alorF d'insdrer dans la loi de liquidation un article ainsi oom; I, eto. Attenda qa'ane analyse des proeds verbaux de la Commission de liquidation ne permet pap encore de ddiouvrirce que les demandeurs prd tendont y 6tre contenu, e'est b dire qu'une id etve a dtd faite an profit d'Ismail pacha an sujet des propridtds des Dairas, que nolle part n'est question du retoor de la proprid d b Ismail pacha, une fois les dettes regldes. Attendu qu'il eat bon d'observer que la si to at ion joridiqne du gouveruement vis-b-vis de 8. A. Ismail pacha en ce qii ooncerne la pro pridte dbs tions des Dairas Sanieb et Khassa a dtd compldtement modifide par la loi de liquidation. Qu'eu rdsumd il y a eu substitution d'ane nouvelle detteb l'aucienne et substitution d'un nouveau ddbiteur b l'ancien, cest-b-dire du gouveruement dgyptien b Ismail pacha. Attendu que les demandeors modifiant les motifs invoqnds par eux dans leur demande, ddolarent qu'ils BO revendiquent pas la propridtd actne'.le des biens Daira, qui a dtd transfdrde b l'Etat, etc Omissis. Attendu que cette reconnaissance du droit de propridtd de l'Etat exclut toute idde de confiscation et qu'il y a lieu d'dtre tout surpris qa'aprds avoir reooflnu qu'il n'y avait pas eu de confiscation, les demandeors avancent qu il y a eu one vdritable expropiiation pour oauss d'utilitd publique. Attendu qu'il n'y a euy ni confiscation ni exportation pour cause d'utilitd publique, d'autant plus que la Commission qui a mani- festement montrd son intention de respeoter 'es intdreta de tons, n'avait pas besoin de proposer ni de confiscation ni d'exportation, rien ne l'empechant de laisser les biens Dairas en propridtd de S.A. bmail pacha, qui aurait eu b so debattre aveo ses ordanciers on bien de mentionr.er dans le projet de loi le mandat sui generis que les demandeors prdtendent avoir dtd donnd b l'Etat, Ismail pacha restant propridtaire de sea biens. Qu'en ddolarant l'E:at propridtaire des biens de S A. Ismail paoha et en mettant b sa charge toutes les dettes de ce dernier, elle n'a agi que dans l'jntdrct personnel de S. A. le Khddive et de ses ordanciers personnels. Attendu que les demandeors soutiennent en qae'que sorte, b titre subsidiaire, que l'Etat ayant fait un bdndfice dnorme par suite de la plus value des terres il n'est pas dquitable qu 'il s'enrobissa indument et qu'il y aurait lieu de fairo application i lear dgaid des dispositions de Part. 11 du code oivil mixte. Attendu que depuis la promulgation de la loi de liquidation, l'Etat est devenu proprid taire des biens des D liras Sanieh et Khassa, et est devenu auaei le vdritable ddbiteur des ordanciers de ces Dairas. Qu'il sensuit que si la valeur de la propridtd foucidre avait baissd, le gouvernement n'aurait pu avoir aucun recours contre Ismail pacha et ses hdritiers, qu'en outre comme propridtaire et ddbiteur il a tout le droit de bdndficier de la plus value dont s'agit. Que leur (des demandeurs) demande eu reddition de compte soit au G)u vernement soit'au Crédit Foncier soit b la Sooidtd Egyp tienne de la Daira Sanieh n'est done pas justifide.

div.head: ARCHITECTURE AND PROGRESS
div.p: Mr. Williams Lecture (Continued from Saturday)

The great architectural works of the ancients whi-h have come down to ns are mainly butUingB that were erected in honour of the religion of the builders or perhaps as much to their own glory as that of the religion ,-h they practised. Iu later times two great rjigi.,11" of the world, rame'y the Chris'iar. aLll the Mohamedan, have left to ns some master monuments in organic architecture. '1'he appointment of Christianity as the' state religion of the Roman world aud the subse- 4 ient fall of the Roman Empire gave Bcope for new thought. The meo of the north and -t the mountains came upon the effete Roman world with new vigour and a fresh, untutored, robrsti.ess of thought and action. The old formalism was dead, the Greek architec- t ral shackles, forged by the Roman?, had fallen off, and architeotarally men were free. Tho new religions required buildings, and forthwith there were born the Byzantine and Romanesque, which later on were followed by the Arabio, Saracenic or Moorish, and Gothic. ' {'he Christian art of the deoliuing empire," aays Ruskin, ' was divided into two great branches: 'Western and Eastern.' One oentred iu Rome, the other at Byzantium, of which the one is the early Christian Romanesque, properly so called, and the other, carried to a higher imaginative perfection by Greek workmen, is distingu'shed from it as Byzantiue." Here at last we see the Greek workman unshackled and at the confines of the east and the west they, in the 6th century, rear their splendid church, dedicated, very properly, to the Holy Wisdom, commonly known as Santa Sophia, and now filling the useful office of a splendid Mohamedan mosque. The Byzantine style spreac into Venice and even to Alexandria. St. Mirk's, Venice, was erected at the end of the 10th century, over the body of St. Mark, which had been obtained from Alexandria, perhaps, a hundred years before, when the Caliph of the day, wanting marbles for a mosq'ie or a residence, ordered the destruction's/ tqe then St. Mark's chnroh, probably a fine Byzantine building. The Arahs were thus unconsciously led to work in the style of the Bjzantiie3 and, in turn, the Byzantine workmen and Venice gave the architecture there an Arabio flavoar, as may be seen by the remains of horseshoe .and 'pointed arches. There are vestjges of Byzin- tine architecture to be seen in the Alexandria and Cairo Museums, and the other day basket-work capital in marble was dug out of a foundation near the rue Adib, the ornamen; tation of which is singularly like some capitals to be found at Ravenna. The development of architecture continued to progress, the Arabs developing, in Spain and Cairo, and wherever they settled down to build, a style which has become peculiarly their own and in time there arose suoh beautiful mosqaes as these of Sultan Hassan and Kaid Bey. In the 12tb, 13tb, & 14tb centuries orgauic architecture had free play and reached its zmith. In Britain it was distinguished b78traighttorwardne3S in construction, honesty in the use of materials, and purity and beauty of form. At first the work WAS heavy and massive. Its eolnmns were great piers built up of small stones, as at Malvern and Tewkesbary.Its tower?, loopholed and em brasored standing fonr square to^storm and enemy alike and its heavy defensive work, in tirpe, gave place to delicately veined and rib bed vaulting which covered tl}3 great nayes of chnrohes like thebroidered veil of a fairy. The ornamentation WAS as trne as it was often profuse. It was organio, tfiat is to say, not applied rr pasted ornament. The mason revelled in his work,Whatever drawbacks the madimval times presented to the lives of the worker, bis work was full of pleasnro, There is not a moulding, that the working of L, in the best Gothio period, did not give joy to tin worker. If at any period in our history there was a time wli3n tho work was worth doing and a source of happiness the woiker as well as to the user, then that time was the 18th century— in building certainly.

div.head: MEMORIAL TO GENERAL GATACRE.
div.p: In memory of General Sir William Gatacre, aimral tablet has been placed in the historic chnroh of Clavering, Shropshire, which is near the ancient home of the Gatacre family, and this was dedicated last week by Canon Hensor, in the presence of Lady Gatacre, M-s. and the Moses Gatacre, of Gatacre, Lord and Lady Davey, General John ^Ltacre, Mr. T Stephen Gatacre, Mifs Gatacre, and others. 'The table1, after recording the late general's military honours, says"Strenuous in action and gifted wi.b an exalted sense of effioienoy and discipline, he trod his path in life with an unswerving devotion to dnty. His simplicity of character, his great courage, and powers of endurance, h»s manly tenderness of heart, won him the admiration and affection of all who knew him." At the foot of the tablet is the inscrjptjpn, "Whom tjie Lord loveth He chaster.etb " Canon Henson said Sir William Gatacre was c jr;«picnou9ly brave among the brave, and ho aLo had the gift of resource in no common degree. When the sun of success was hidden in cload?, wher, in fac*-, he sustained the hitter experience of professional eclipse, he bore himself with a reticence and with a dignity which commanded univenal respect

div.head: PITCH OF THE PRESS
div.p: THE EDUCATION BILL CLAUSES.

The Government oan now congratulate them selves on havieg carried through Committei what Mr. Birrell calls the "spinal oorAUfcfif the measure. On paper it is not a ver instalment, but then as we have been rernin el, it affirms great principles. The Govern- ment have ca-ried it unaltered, as it was to be expected that they would do. They have not indeed, made much attempt to treat the amendments seriously.'preferring to say as a rule, that they were more appropriate to the clauses that came next. It is, no donbt, a feature of the Bill that very similar issues can be raised oo all its early clauses. ("Times.") No Secularism. People do not want the elementary ducation of this country to be purely secular ; they do not wish to break the old association between the State .and the teaching of religion to the young. Of oonrse, it was open to Mr. Maddison and his friends to say, as they did say, that religions instruction might still be given in the schools, despite their amendment, though not in sohool hours, and cot at the public expense. Bot it was universally allowed that for all practical pur- poses the carrying of Mr. Madditon's amend- ment won'd have banished religious teaching from the schools of the people, inasmuch as instruction not given within sohool hoars is sure to languish. (' Telegraph.") Tho Endowment of Nonconformity, Thodebatoon the first clause of the Educa- tion Bill has fully justified ths hardest things which have been .-aid about the Bill. It is no mit-use of words to speak of the 'endowment of Nonconformity' or 'the destruction of Church schools.' The Bill effects both these objeots, so dear to that section of the Government's supporters which in this matter of education it fears most. . . . Tin passage of the first Clauss leave3 England with the certain and sore prospect of a steady deolino of religious belief. ("Morning Post")International Arbitration. The oongrefs of members of Parliament and others favourable to international arbitration, which is to meet in London in the last week of July, will have the use of Westminster Hall. In al', there will be upwards of 500 delegates, France being represented by some 60 or 70, and London by close upon SOI Repr^enta tivea of Bavaria, Sixony, and Wurtembnrg have also bem invited. The conference proper will oconpy three days. ("Standard.* ) . Germany's Colonial Policy. The events of the last few days show that the people of Germany are growing more and more sceptical of the advantages of the system which has produced the protracted and inglorious war in German S. W. Africa. Liberals of other countries will welcome any signs of the determination of the people of Germany to have a larger share in the direction of their own affairp.and they cannot mi-s the significan-ce of a revolt which is directed against policies and schemes iff which the Emperor's interest is particularly intimate. ("Tribune.") Nogl and Stasssel. Report has it that General Nogi has te'.e- graphed to the Russian Government, inquiring whether it is true that General Stceseel has bean sentenced to death, and expressing the opinion that the surrender of Port Arthur waa quite jnati^ei in the oiroumstances. The oircumstances were peculiar, certainly. Stunsel had not surrendered, he might have been there yet. ("Qlobe.") The Colonial Conference. It is evident that Lord Elgin has nothing to propose. Therefore, he must be calling the Conference for the purpose of learning what the Colonies have to advise for the common good Wore they to respond by sending delegates to urge the establishment of preferential trado relations with the Mother country, the Confer ence would be embarrassing to the British Government, although it would probably evoke a sympathetic feeling in the British people. (' Mail and Empire," Toronto.)

div.head: THE,SECRET OF "EDWIN DROOD"
div.p: Charles Dickens's younger. daughter, Mr?. Perngini, has set ber?elf io the Jane- number of the "Pall. Mali Magazine" to throw very welo me light upon the one enigma of her father's works, "The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the story he left ha'f told at the time of his Mrs. Peragini's first husband designed the cover for the novel, and she herself helped to tend the novelist when the labour of the book was bringing his life to an untimely end. She now explains that the story was so in- eparablc in her mindfrom her father's memory that she coaid never bear to look on it until lately; bat finding that so much gnesawork has been expended on the invention of a sequel,]: ?he gives her reasons for believing that tfie theory of John Forster, the biographer, is the right one, and that all others suggesting Drood's resurrection are futile and uqreaeoi able. My father, she writes, told his plot to^Mr. Forster, as he had been accustomed to tell his plots for years past ; and those who knew him must feel it impossible to believe that in this, the last year of his life, he should suddenly become underhand, and we might say treacherous, to his old friend, by inventing for his private edification a plot that he had no intention of oarrying into execution. That he did not write to Mr. Forster to tell him of any divergence from his second plan for the book we all know, and we know also that my eldest brother, Charles, positively declared that he had heard from his father's lips that Edwin Drood was dead. Here, therefore, are two very important witnesses to a fact that is still doubted by those who never met my father, and werentfver impressed by the grave sincerity with which hewould\have given this assurance. Havieg known both Mr. Forstor and my brother intimately, I oannot for a moment believe that either of them would speak or write that which he did not know to be strictly true : and it is on these grounds alone that I think I have a right to be heard when I insist □pun the assertion that Edwin Drood was undoubtedly murdered by his uncle Jasper. Upon reading the book once more, as have already told, after an interval of a great number of years, the story took such entire possession of me that -for a long time I could think of nothing else j and one day, my aont, Miss Hogarth, being with me, I asked her if she knew anything more definite than I did as to how the ending was to be brought about. My aunt Baid that she knew absolutely nothing, but she told me that shortly before my father's death, and after he had been speaking of some difficulty he was in with his work, without explaining what it was, ?he found it impossible to refrain from asking him, "I hope yon haven't really killed poor Edwin Drood I" To which he gravely replied, I call my book the Mystery, not the History, of Edwin Drood." And that waa all he would answer. ... y That my father's brain was more than usually dear and bright during the writing of1 Edwin Drood," no one who lived with him could possibly doubt; and the extraordinary interest he took in the development cf this story was apparent in all that he said or did, and was often the subjeot of conversation between those who anxiously watched him as he wrote, and tearel that he waa tiying his strength too far. Any attempt to Btay him, however, in work that he had undertaken was as idle as stretching one's hands to a river and bidding it cease to flow ; and bey end a few remon strances now and again urged, no such attempt was made, knowing as we did that it would be entirely useless. And so the work sped on oarrying with it my father's few remaining days of life, and the end came all foo soon, to one who never oeased to labour for those who ware dear to him, in the hope of gaining for them that which he was destined never to enjoy. And in my father's grave lies buried the seoret of his story

div.head: TURCO-PERSIAN FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: BASIS OF THE SETTLEMENT. Lord Reay asked the Under secretary for Foreign Affairs in the House of Lords last week, if he could give any information in regard to the settlement of the frontier dispute between Turkey and Persia near Vazueh and Soj-Bula. Loid Fitzmaurice, in the course of bis reply' said a diepute had arisen between Persia and Turkey in regard to the boundary in the neighbourhood of the place3 mentioned by the noble lord, in the Knrd districts, on the borders ot those two countries. Negotiations were now proceeding, and there was eveiy reason to believe that an amicable settlement of the question would be arived at. The Government understood that the question would now be decided locally between the two Governments, and they had received information that a Persian Commissioner bai left to meet the Turkish Commissioner on the iron tier. This evidently was a most desirable solution. The question had been -.treated at Con stantinople, and the Persian Ambassador there had had the benefit of receiving advice from the British and Rastian Ambassadors in regard to the matter. In J 851 Lord Palmerston proposed that the general line of frontier between Turkey and Persia should be traced by the agents of those two Powers at Constantinople, assisted by Commissioners, in conformity with the stipnla •iir.s of the Treaty of Etzeronm cf 1847 8, having doubtful localities to be settled in detail in the future. The Russian Govern-ment agreed to this propose1, and the work of surveying the o >untry from Moont Ararat to the Persian Gulf wvs then commenced. When this was done the preparation of a ap of the Tarco Persian frontier, embraoing territory 700 miles in length by from 20 to 40 miles broad, was put in hand. This work lasted from November, 1857, to March, 1865 aud would doubtless be the basis of the present settlement

div.head: GREEK AT CAMBRIDGE.
div.p: THE "OPTIONAL" PROPOSALS DEFEATED.

'The voting on the second report of the Studies and Examinations Syndicate, proposing a bifarcafion of studies info scienoe and letters, and making Greek optional for science men, was continued in the SenateHouee, Cambridge, last week, and the result was declared as under:— Non-Placet 747 Placet 241 Majority against 606 The vote on the first report in March, 1905, wasNon-Placet, 1557 ; Placet, 1055. Two senior wranglers and two brothers were seen voting in opposite ways. The Master of the Rolls paired for the Non- Placet, whilst Mr. Justice Kennedy would have come up to vote against, if votes had been wanted. The following were among these who voted :—- Placet.—The Bishop of Ely, the Master of Christ's, the Master of Corpus, and Professors Sir George Darwin, V. H. Stanton, Howard Marsh, and Sims Woodhead. Non Placed. - Lord Macnagh'er, Lord Bray brooke, the Master of Clare, Mr. R. Horton Smith, K.C., Mr. J. £. P. Rawlinson, K.C., M.P., S. W. Qcayle Jones (late Chief J aBtioe of Sierra Leone), and Professors Swete and ald^teib. It is understood tint unless the oounoil submita^a_£race for . the oontinuanoe of the life of the Studies Syndicate it will lapse. Now that the Studies Syndicate and its proposals no longer stand in the way, the Non-placet party will at once push forward the soheme of reform which they have inaugurated—namely. a joint Oxford and Cam-bridge matriculation examination, in which shall be inolnded compulsory scienoe and compulsory Greek. There is a pretty universal feeling that reform is possible, but not the partionlar reforms which have been advocated by the Studies Syndicate on the last two occasion reforms which would aot up'oo thc schools as well as the university — a mattefi entirely neglected in both the proposals wnich have lately been before the Senate. It is held to be most important that whatever is done should be calculated to raise the standard of every average boy in all the schools which can be influenced by the university.

Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE " Egyptian Gazette. "

The Commercial and Finanoial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement oontains exhaustive and important reviews of the ootton, cotton seed, and stock and share market0, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the oopies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For farther particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
